case_vignette: A 67-year-old male presents to your office one day after an injury. Yesterday he tried to play basketball with his grandchildren and he was doing well until he jumped to get the ball and landed awkwardly on his right foot, after which he could not bear weight on his foot. On exam, his right foot is significant for swelling with tenderness to palpation anterior to the Achilles tendon. The patient has no tenderness over his medial or lateral malleoli. Figure A is a radiograph of his right foot with the area of traumatic injury.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I injured myself playing basketball, and now my right foot is swollen and it hurts a lot right in front of the spot where the back of my ankle ends. I can't put any weight on it.

No, I haven't had any previous ankle injuries or surgeries.

There's no information provided about me taking any medications for other medical conditions.
Have you had any family history of ankle injuries or surgeries?
The case vignette doesn't provide any information about my family history of ankle injuries or surgeries.
Final Diagnosis: Ankle Sprain
